qas.question: Which company worked with Apple in creating the user interface for the iPod?
What was the name of the font used prior to the release of the iPod Mini?
In what year was the 6th gen iPod Classic released?
The 6th gen iPod Classic and 3rd gen iPod nano featured which font?
Who supervised the design and implementation of the iPod user interface?
What software did Apple use as the basis for their iPod software?
What typeface does the current iPod use?

context: Apple did not develop the iPod software entirely in-house, instead using <a5_0>PortalPlayer<a5_0/>'s reference platform based on two ARM cores. The platform had rudimentary software running on a commercial microkernel embedded operating system. PortalPlayer had previously been working on an IBM-branded MP3 player with Bluetooth headphones. Apple contracted another company, <a0_0>Pixo<a0_0/>, to help design and implement the user interface under the direct supervision of <a4_0>Steve Jobs<a4_0/>. As development progressed, Apple continued to refine the software's look and feel. Starting with the iPod Mini, the <a1_0>Chicago<a1_0/> font was replaced with Espy Sans. Later iPods switched fonts again to Podium Sans—a font similar to Apple's corporate font, Myriad. iPods with color displays then adopted some Mac OS X themes like Aqua progress bars, and brushed metal meant to evoke a combination lock. In <a2_0>2007<a2_0/>, Apple modified the iPod interface again with the introduction of the sixth-generation iPod Classic and third-generation iPod Nano by changing the font to <a3_0><a6_0>Helvetica<a6_0/><a3_0/> and, in most cases, splitting the screen in half by displaying the menus on the left and album artwork, photos, or videos on the right (whichever was appropriate for the selected item).
